thread.title_full: Miami Heat add Briante Weber, cut Corey Hawkins - Sun Sentinel

author: Ira Winderman
title: Miami Heat add Briante Weber, cut Corey Hawkins
text:
In moves related to their NBA Development League affiliate, the Miami Heat on Monday waived undrafted rookie guard Corey Hawkins and signed undrafted rookie guard Briante Weber.
Both are ultimately expected to join the Heat's D-League affiliate, the Sioux Falls Skyforce.
By adding Weber with just one week left in training camp, it allows the Heat to offer the defensive specialist out of Virginia Commonwealth a small payment in order to facilitate his direct assignment to the D-League.
The Heat made a similar move last year, when they signed guard Larry Drew II during the final week of training camp and then waived him five days later, with Drew then spending the season in Sioux Falls.
Hawkins, the 3-point specialist out of Cal-Davis, had played sparingly in the preseason for the Heat. He played five minutes in Saturday's road victory over the Houston Rockets in his preseason debut, converting his only shot, a 3-pointer. He then played nine minutes in Sunday's road victory over the Atlanta Hawks, again converting his lone shot, also a 3-point attempt. He also had two rebounds and an assist in that appearance.

See more videos The moves leave the Heat with the NBA-maximum 20 players in training camp. In addition to Hawkins and Weber likely reporting to Sioux Falls, the Heat also are positioned to have current roster longshots Greg Whittington and Keith Benson also assigned to their D-League affiliate.
The Heat have two remaining preseason games before opening their regular season on Oct. 28 at AmericanAirlines Arena against the Charlotte Hornets.
NBA teams must trim to a maximum of 15 players on Oct. 26, with the Heat's final cuts expected by Saturday, in advance of the 48-hour waiver period.
Weber played four seasons at Virginia Commonwealth, appearing in 127 games and averaged 6.8 points, 3.3 rebounds, 3.0 assists, 2.94 steals and 23.4 minutes while shooting .426 from the field. He finished as VCU's all-time career steals leader, finishing third on the NCAA all-time steals list. He became the first player in conference history to be named the Atlantic 10 Defensive Player of the Year in three consecutive seasons.
